abstract.text: Obtains the trust settings for a certificate.

inlineContent.text: The certificate for which you want the trust settings. Pass the value
to obtain the default root certificate trust settings for the domain.
The domain from which you want to get trust settings. For possible values, see
On return, an array of
objects that specify the trust settings for the certificate. For the contents of the dictionaries, see the discussion below. In Objective-C, call the
function to release this object when you’re finished with it.
A result code. See
. Returns
if no trust settings exist for the specified certificate and domain.
The system expresses each certificate’s trust settings as a
that includes any number (including zero) of dictionaries of type
, each of which describes one set of usage constraints. Each usage-constraints dictionary may contain any of the following key-value pairs:
A policy object (
) that specifies the certificate verification policy; for example: TLS or SMIME. Create a policy object using the
functions; for example, to create a standard TLS verification policy, use
A trusted application reference (
) for the app that checks the certificate’s trust settings. Use the
function to get this reference.
A
that contains policy-specific data. For an SMIME policy, this string contains an email address. For a TLS policy, it contains a host name.
A
that contains an
value specifying the operations that can use the encryption key in this certificate. For possible values, see
A
that contains an
value indicating the effective trust setting for this usage-constraints dictionary.

The system includes a usage-constraints dictionary in its evaluation of trust for a certificate only if the policy, application, and key use given in the dictionary match the use for which the system is evaluating the certificate. If this is the case, then the system combines the value of the
key with the values from other matching dictionaries to determine the overall trust setting for the certificate, using a logical
operation.
If this key isn’t present, the system assumes a default value of
. Only a root certificate can have this value; therefore it’s invalid to create a usage-constraints dictionary for a non-root certificate without this key.
For the possible values for this key, see
A
that contains an
value indicating a
result code. If the system encounters this result code due to an error when it evaluates the trust for a certificate, it ignores the error.
The system applies this “allowed error” value to the certificate evaluation only if the usage-constraints dictionary meets the criteria described with the
key. A usage-constraints dictionary with no constraints but with an allowed error value causes the system to always ignore that value when evaluating a certificate.

The system determines the overall trust settings for a certificate by combining the trust-settings results from all the usage-constraints dictionaries that match the use for which it’s evaluating the certificate. Trust settings for a given use apply if
any
of the dictionaries in the certificate’s trust-settings array matches the specified use.
If the value of the
key is a value other than
for a usage constraints-dictionary that has no constraints, the system uses the default value
. To specify a value for the
component without explicitly trusting or distrusting the associated certificate, set the value of the
key to
The
parameter can return a valid but empty
. This empty trust-settings array means “always trust this certificate” with an overall trust setting for the certificate of
. However, an empty trust settings array isn’t the same as no trust settings, where the
parameter returns
. No trust-settings array means “this certificate must be verifiable using a known trusted certificate”.
The trust settings result value
can only apply to root (self-signed) certificates. It’s an error to apply it to non-root certificates, including implicitly by using an empty trust settings array. Instead, use

The system authenticates the person before making changes to per-user trust settings. On macOS 11 and later, the system authenticates the person as an administrator before making changes to system-wide trust settings. Therefore, you can only modify trust settings when running in a GUI environment; for example, a launch daemon can’t modify the settings.

abstract.text: Releases a Core Foundation object.
A reference to an immutable array object.
A reference to an immutable dictionary object.
A reference to a CFNumber object.
A reference to a CFString object.
Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An abstract Core Foundation-type object representing an X.509 certificate.
An object that represents a trust policy.
Returns a policy object for evaluating SSL certificate chains.
Obtains the trust settings for a certificate.
The trust settings domains.
Allowed uses for the encryption key in a certificate.
Trust settings returned in usage constraints dictionaries.
This non-root certificate is explicitly trusted as if it were a trusted root.
This root certificate is explicitly trusted.
This certificate is neither trusted nor distrusted. This value can be used to specify an “allowed error” without assigning trust to a specific certificate.
An opaque type that contains information about a trusted app.
Creates a trusted app instance based on the app at the given path in the file system.
The item cannot be found.
A number which, if encountered during certificate verification, is ignored for that certificate.
A trusted application reference for the application checking the certificate’s trust settings.
A value indicating the default root certificate trust settings when used as a certificate object in a trust settings API function.
A number specifying the operations for which the encryption key in this certificate can be used.
A policy object specifying the certificate verification policy.
A string containing policy-specific data.
A number indicating the effective trust setting for this usage constraints dictionary.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
A reference to an immutable array object.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
